DOC.HEAD: Controversy Over Whether Reporters Should Have Been Allowed Closer
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military in Panama opened the doors to about 350 journalists today after two days of controversy about restrictions put on the small pool of reporters who accompanied the original troops. Some 50 newsmen and women arrived by charter plane late Thursday from Costa Rica, and the U.S. Southern Command, based in Panama, was bracing for the arrival early today of a jumbo jet carrying up to 300 more. A special media pool, in its most significant test since the concept was created, was activated Tuesday night and flown from Washington to Panama. However, military officers on Wednesday kept the journalists from actually covering any hostilities. Military commanders in Panama are doing their best to protect members of the media covering the U.S. military action in that country, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said. Asked about the problem, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater had a complaint of his own, claiming that a news organization had broken pool security. He would not name the organization. ``We were greatly disturbed that one of the major organizations had divulged their participation and departure before they left here,'' Fitzwater said. It ``does call into question the integrity of the pool and the commitments made,'' he said. News organizations which take part in the pool agree in advance to keep its activation a secret. Tuesday night, the pool was activated about six hours before the military assault was announced publicly. Military officials in Panama said Thursday they would let the new wave of reporters camp in the officer's club restaurant initially but expected them to have their own accommodations by Friday. Fitzwater's complaint about security was not echoed by the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin Powell. ``I think it worked marvelously the other evening,'' he said. ``We did what we promised you we would do and the media in the pool did what they promised they would do,'' he said. Pool members gathered late Tuesday night and were flown to Panama with the invasion force under a promise of secrecy. ``There never was any concern in my mind it would break security and it didn't,'' said Powell. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams, sitting with Cheney in an interview with newspaper and wire service reporters, acknowledged that ``we wish we could have done a better job getting people around'' on Wednesday. ``I think there was adequate coverage. I think our commanders on the scene had their priorities straight,'' said Cheney, noting that media executives had called his office demanding that the military protect reporters who were not in the pool. A photographer who was not in the pool was killed, and other journalists were taken hostage by forces loyal to ousted Panamanian Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Before the joint Cheney-Powell interview, Williams was asked why pool members had been restricted largely to interviews with U.S. Embassy officials during most of the first day of the invasion. He responded: ``Incompetence ... There really is no excuse for it.''
